Dowling okay so Dowling when it comes to
wedding cakes are traditionally tiered
cakes where each tier gets smaller on
the way up
Dowling is fairly simple my general
rules are I use about one down to
represent each inch that the cake is so
for example if I was stacking a 9-inch
cake on top of the 12 inch cake I would
put nine dowels into that 12 inch cake
to hold up that 9 inch cake and what I
would do is create a circle like a clock
and I would do eight dowels in that
circle and then one in the center
sometimes depending on the cake it's
necessary to run one entire Darrell
dowel through the whole cake in that
case I would leave out that centered L
if the nine-inch cake let's say was
higher
so therefore heavier or if it was some
kind of a shape going on to the 12-inch
cake then I might up those dowels to 12
to be safe rather than sorry we're gonna
get tricky is when you start to work
with novelty and shaped cakes because
it's really dependent on where the
weight lies you know if more of the

put more devils there also height is a
factor so generally dowels aren't sort

six inches of height on the cake so if
you know you're building a cake that's

board but if I were if that cake was

three inches because I knew the cup was

and therefore heavier at the top and you
will notice if you don't dowel if any of
